summary: This is a court order from a FOIA lawsuit filed by The New York Times against the Federal Bureau of Prisons, seeking documents related to the circumstances of Jeffrey Epstein's 2019 suicide. The judge orders the BOP to submit withheld records for in-camera review, as the BOP's justification for withholding them under FOIA Exemption 7(A) is insufficiently detailed, citing potential interference with two other pending prosecutions.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The FOIA case concerns the circumstances surrounding his 2019 suicide while in BOP custody.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: The BOP cites his pending prosecution as one of two that could be disrupted by the disclosure of withheld documents related to Epstein's death.

persons.name: Tova Noel
persons.context: The BOP cites her pending prosecution as one of two that could be disrupted by the disclosure of withheld documents related to Epstein's death.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: The BOP cites his pending prosecution as one of two that could be disrupted by the disclosure of withheld documents related to Epstein's death.

persons.name: Paul A. Engelmayer
persons.context: The judge presiding over the FOIA case, who issued this order directing the BOP to provide withheld records for in-camera review.

persons.name: Christenson
persons.context: Filed a supplemental declaration (Dkt. 39-1) with Exhibit 1 identifying withheld records.

connections.description: Both are named as defendants in a pending prosecution cited by the BOP.
The BOP was the custodian of Jeffrey Epstein at the time of his death.

events.title: Suicide of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide while in the custody of the Federal Bureau of Prisons.

events.title: FOIA Case Argument
events.description: The court held an argument in the FOIA case concerning documents about Epstein's suicide.

events.title: Court Order for In-Camera Review
events.description: Judge Engelmayer ordered the BOP to provide withheld documents for in-camera review by May 14, 2021.

keyFacts: The Federal Bureau of Prisons is withholding documents related to Jeffrey Epstein's 2019 suicide under FOIA Exemption 7(A), claiming disclosure could interfere with the pending prosecutions of Nicholas Tartaglione and Tova Noel and Michael Thomas.

The court found the BOP's justification for withholding the documents insufficiently detailed, failing to show a 'rational link' between the documents and potential interference with the cited prosecutions.
Judge Paul A. Engelmayer ordered the BOP to submit the withheld records for in-camera review, with a schedule for all records to be provided by May 14, 2021.
The FOIA lawsuit was filed by The New York Times Company seeking transparency into the circumstances surrounding Epstein's death in BOP custody.
The document is a court order, not the withheld records themselves, indicating an ongoing legal battle for information about Epstein's suicide.
